Award.AwardTitle: Nonparametric Inference of Nonstationary Time Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to advance the development of statistical methodology and theory for analyzing nonstationary time series. A nonstationary time series is a sequence of data points collected at successive time points with certain aspects changing over time or being nonstationary. Nonstationary time series appear very frequently in various scientific fields including economics, engineering, environmental science, finance, and medical science among others. Ignoring nonstationarity and dependence, two important features of nonstationary time series, can lead to erroneous conclusions. Therefore, the research project is expected to promote scientific research in not only statistics but also other disciplines that involve the analysis of nonstationary time series.

In order to capture the temporal dynamics resulting from the nonstationarity, the parameters are allowed to change over time and modeled as deterministic but unknown functions of time, which are intrinsically infinite dimensional. To avoid potential misspecifications of parametric models, nonparametric methods are used to estimate and make inference about the underlying parameter functions. The research to be performed involves parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, and variable selection for regression models with time-varying parameters. By allowing a general class of nonstationary and dependent processes, the methods to be developed and the asymptotic results to be established can be widely applicable, and we are able to understand and quantify the effect of nonstationarity and dependence on the asymptotic behavior of parameter estimators and test statistics of interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project develops novel statistical theory and methods for analyzing nonstationary time series, an important data type that arises in economics, engineering, environmental science, finance, medical science and many other areas. For nonstationary time series data, the popular assumption of stationarity does not hold, and we develop nonparametric and semiparametric methods to capture and statistically describe potential time-varying features of the underlying process. We use deep probabilistic tools such as the martingale approximation and the Gaussian approximation to study the effect of dependence on interested statistics and establish the associated asymptotic theory. The project has led to the development of new theory and methods for detecting and testing the existence of time-varying features, estimating time-varying parameters as functions of time with pointwise and uniform measures of uncertainty, learning and understanding the relationship among multiple nonstationary time series, and assessing the degree of plausibility of parametric and semiparametric models. Our results have been applied to climate science, economics and finance.

The research findings not only provide a number of novel statistical tools for analyzing nonstationary time series data but also shed light on approaches that one can take to statistically handle nonstationarity and dependence at the same time. Our theoretical and empirical studies demonstrate that nonstationarity and dependence can both have striking effects on the asymptotic behavior of statistics of interest, and as a result ignoring them can lead to erroneous conclusions. Therefore, our research results are expected to promote scientific research and open new avenues for future research in various disciplines that involve the analysis of nonstationary time series. Many of the newly developed theory and methods have been directly applied to problems in these disciplines including, for example, assessing global warming through a time-varying trend analysis in climate science, finding reasonable statistical models to explain the dynamics of interest rates in economics, and understanding the time-varying relationship among various stock prices in finance.

The project also contributes to undergraduate and graduate education, where some of the research results have been simplified and taught in the classroom. It also contributes to training a new generation of statisticians and data scientists. The developed software and algorithms can also be implemented with possible modifications by students and other researchers.
